sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.title: ESPQ: Quantum-Safe Encapsulation Security Payload
sciknow-25x1-scientific-papers.abstract: The significance of virtual private networks (VPN) has increased rapidly over time. Enterprises utilize IPsec and other VPN technologies to provide a secure connection to mission-critical resources over the internet. The various subprotocols of IPsec i.e., Encapsulation Security Payload (ESP) and Authentication Header (AH) provide confidentiality and integrity through the encryption mechanisms. Unfortunately, recent studies indicate that the traditional encryption techniques employed in IPsec could face a potential threat from the progress of quantum computing. To address this issue, this research proposes an improved Encapsulation Security Payload for Quantum Safety (ESPQ) which can serve as a post-quantum encryption and authentication algorithm for VPN networks. The proposed algorithm incorporates modern quantum-safe algorithms into its framework. Through extensive research and analysis of performance metrics, it has become evident that ESPQ surpasses the conventional methodology of ESP both in terms of heightened security safeguards and reduced system load requirements.

sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.name: ESPQ: Quantum-Safe Encapsulation Security Payload Methodological Framework
sciknow-25x1-methodological-frameworks.description: The study proposes an improved Encapsulation Security Payload for Quantum Safety (ESPQ) to provide quantum-proof integrity and confidentiality for VPN networks. The methodology involves developing a sandbox network system topology, integrating post-quantum cryptography (PQC) algorithms, and evaluating the performance and security of the proposed ESPQ against conventional methods.

studyDesign.designDetails: The study uses a simulated network environment to test the ESPQ protocol's performance and security. The design includes a sandbox network with enterprise networks, forward proxies, and thin clients to mimic real-world VPN usage.

steps.description: Develop a sandbox network system topology with two enterprise networks and multiple interconnected subnetworks.
Position servers at the edge of each network to function as forward proxies for packet encapsulation and decapsulation.
Implement the ESPQ protocol with PQC algorithms on the proxies and test packet routing through a logical tunnel.
Evaluate the performance and security of the ESPQ protocol by sending ESPQ packets and analyzing the results.

procedures.procedureDescription: The procedure involves setting up a sandbox network, implementing the ESPQ protocol with various PQC algorithms, and conducting tests to evaluate performance and security.

dataAnalysis.summary: The study analyzes the performance and security of the ESPQ protocol by sending packets through the sandbox network and evaluating the effectiveness of signature-based PQC algorithms and payload encryption algorithm NTRU. The analysis includes multiple cycles of packet transfers and comparisons with conventional encryption methods.

resultsRepresentation.summary: The results indicate that the ESPQ protocol, when integrated with the tested PQC algorithms, provides quantum-safe integrity and confidentiality for VPN networks. The findings show that ESPQ surpasses conventional ESP in terms of security and system load requirements.
